1.name: Olfactory Bulb
1.description: Processes odorant information from sensory neurons and relays it to higher-order brain regions such as the amygdala, orbitofrontal cortex (OFC), and hippocampus. OFC and hippocampal inputs are received indirectly via the piriform and entorhinal cortices, respectively. [1]
functions: Mediates local odor discrimination [1]
Permits higher brain areas involved in arousal and attention to modulate odor detection and discrimination [1]
connections: Receives a single source of olfactory input: axons from olfactory receptor neurons in the olfactory epithelium [1]
Outputs via mitral and tufted cell axons to the anterior olfactory nucleus (AON), piriform cortex, amygdala, and entorhinal cortex [1]
Receives top-down modulation from the olfactory cortex, amygdala, neocortex, hippocampus, locus coeruleus, and substantia nigra [1]

2.name: Anterior Olfactory Nucleus
2.description: An early relay and processing area for olfactory information, located posterior to the olfactory bulb and within the olfactory tract. [1] It integrates and distributes odor signals between hemispheres and provides modulatory feedback to the olfactory bulb. [2]
functions: Plays a pivotal, though relatively poorly understood, role in the processing of odor information [1]
Distributes odor information across hemispheres via the anterior commissure [2]
Provides feedback modulation to the olfactory bulb [2]
connections: Receives input from the ipsilateral olfactory bulb [1]
Sends projections to the contralateral olfactory bulb via the anterior commissure [2]
Projects ipsilaterally to the piriform cortex and other olfactory cortical areas [2]

3.name: Piriform Cortex
3.description: Located between the insula and temporal lobe, the piriform cortex serves as a primary olfactory cortical area that relays odor information to higher-order brain regions. It exhibits characteristics of an association cortex, integrating individual odor components into unified perceptual representations. [1][2]
functions: Integrates olfactory bulb input into perceptual odor representations [2]
Contributes to odor learning, memory, and associative processing [2][3]
connections: Receives afferents from the olfactory bulb via axons of mitral and tufted cells [3]
Has reciprocal connections with the prefrontal cortex, amygdala, perirhinal cortex, and entorhinal cortex [2]
Sends outputs to the orbitofrontal cortex via the mediodorsal thalamus [2]

4.name: Anterior (Agranular) Insular Cortex
4.description: The most anterior portion of the insula, identified cytoarchitecturally by the absence or extreme thinning of granular cortical layers II and IV (i.e., agranular) [1][2][3]. The insular cortex more broadly serves as a hub integrating visceral, emotional, and interoceptive signals, linking internal bodily states to subjective awareness and higher-order cognitive–affective processes [2][3][4].
functions: Mediates attention to internal bodily signals (e.g., heartbeat, respiration) [4]
Integrates autonomic, cognitive, and emotional inputs to support subjective feeling states and emotional awareness [2][4]
Engages during perception of bodily or emotional states in others (vicarious or empathic processing) [2]
Serves as a hub for detecting salient internal or external events and mediating switching among large-scale brain networks (e.g., default mode, executive) [4]
connections: Exhibits reciprocal projections with multiple amygdaloid nuclei, including the basolateral nucleus [4]
Receives interoceptive input via brainstem–thalamic pathways and from posterior insular regions [3][4]
Strongly connected with the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), prefrontal cortex (PFC, including orbitofrontal regions), and other limbic structures [3][4]
Maintains bidirectional projections with middle (dysgranular) and posterior insular subregions, facilitating anterior–posterior integration along the insular axis [4]

5.name: Posterior (Agranular/Dysgranular) Insular Cortex
5.description: The insular cortex displays a cytoarchitectural gradient from anterior agranular to posterior dysgranular/granular cortex. The anterior portion lacks well-defined granular layers (II and IV), while the posterior portion contains a partially developed layer IV, reflecting a transition toward sensory cortical organization [1][2]. Functionally, the insula integrates visceral, somatosensory, and emotional information: the posterior regions are primarily involved in primary interoceptive and somatosensory representation, whereas anterior regions contribute to subjective awareness and affective integration [2][3].
functions: The posterior insula represents internal bodily states such as pain, temperature, and visceral sensations; anterior regions transform these into conscious awareness [2][3].
connections: Receives interoceptive and nociceptive input via posterior thalamic nuclei [3]
Exhibits bidirectional connections with somatosensory cortices (S1/S2), orbitofrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, and amygdala [2][3]
Maintains extensive reciprocal connections along the anterior–posterior insular axis, supporting the transformation of sensory input into emotional and cognitive representations [1][2]

6.name: Head of Caudate
6.description: The anterior, bulbous portion of the caudate nucleus, located adjacent to the lateral ventricle. It is primarily involved in goal-directed action selection, working memory, and cognitive components of motor control [1][2].
functions: Supports adaptive decision making by tracking action–outcome contingencies [2]
Participates in executive processes including planning, attention, and working memory via prefrontal circuits [1][3]
connections: Receives glutamatergic inputs from dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) [2]
Projects to the globus pallidus and substantia nigra pars reticulata via direct and indirect striatal pathways [1][3]

7.name: Body of Caudate
7.description: The elongated central segment of the caudate nucleus, curving along the lateral ventricle’s body. It contributes to cognitive–motor coordination and saccadic eye movement control [1][2].
functions: Integrates feedback and motivational information into motor output [1]
Participates in habit learning and cortico-striatal loops for saccadic control [2]
connections: Receives projections from association cortices and intralaminar thalamic nuclei [1]
Projects to the external globus pallidus and substantia nigra pars reticulata [1][3]

8.name: Tail of Caudate
8.description: The posterior tapering segment of the caudate nucleus that arches into the temporal lobe, adjacent to the amygdala. It connects striatal circuitry with visual and limbic areas [1][2].
functions: Supports visual attention, spatial learning, and reward prediction for peripheral stimuli [2][3]
Mediates associative learning linking visual cues with action outcomes [2]
connections: Receives projections from visual association cortex and superior colliculus [3]
Sends outputs via striatonigral and striatopallidal pathways to substantia nigra and globus pallidus [1][3]

9.name: Putamen
9.description: The putamen is the lateral portion of the dorsal striatum, located adjacent to the globus pallidus and separated from the caudate nucleus by the internal capsule. It forms the larger lateral component of the lentiform nucleus and shares a nearly identical cytoarchitecture with the caudate, consisting predominantly of medium spiny GABAergic projection neurons (~95%). These neurons are organized into neurochemical compartments (striosomes and matrix) and are modulated by dense dopaminergic input from the substantia nigra. The putamen is essential to cortico-basal ganglia loops, integrating cortical inputs and influencing motor and cognitive outputs via downstream basal ganglia pathways [1][2][3].
functions: Regulates initiation and execution of voluntary movements [1][2]
Supports procedural and habit learning through reinforcement-based plasticity [2][3]
Integrates somatosensory feedback for real-time motor adjustments [2]
Contributes to cognitive and reward-related processes, including language, decision-making, and addiction [2][3]
connections: Receives topographically organized excitatory inputs from primary motor, somatosensory, and premotor cortices [1][2]
Dopaminergic input from substantia nigra pars compacta modulates learning and plasticity [2]
Projects to globus pallidus (internal and external segments) and substantia nigra pars reticulata via direct and indirect GABAergic pathways [1][2]
Connected with thalamic motor nuclei (e.g. VA/VL), completing cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical loops [2]
Receives inputs from intralaminar thalamic nuclei (e.g. centromedian) and serotonergic brainstem sources [2]

10.name: Nucleus Accumbens
10.description: The nucleus accumbens (NAc) is a ventral striatal structure located at the junction of the caudate and putamen, anterior to the internal capsule and adjacent to the septal area. It is subdivided into a limbic-connected shell and a motor-related core, and plays a central role in reward processing, motivation, and reinforcement learning [1].
functions: Assigns motivational salience to cues and promotes goal-directed behavior [1]
Processes pleasure, reward, and reinforcement learning [2]
Participates in aversion, action-outcome evaluation, and habit formation [1]
connections: Receives glutamatergic inputs from medial prefrontal cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, hippocampus, and basolateral amygdala [1]
Receives dopaminergic input from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) via the mesolimbic pathway [1]
Projects to the ventral pallidum and mediodorsal thalamus, influencing prefrontal cortex [1]
Sends outputs to the hypothalamus, amygdala, VTA, and brainstem regions including the pedunculopontine tegmentum [1]

11.name: External Segment of Globus Pallidus
11.description: Lateral pallidal segment that implements the indirect basal ganglia pathway to suppress competing motor programs.
functions: Shapes movement by relaying inhibitory signals within the indirect basal ganglia circuit.
Regulates rhythmic activity important for gait and posture.
connections: Receives GABAergic input from striatal medium spiny neurons of the indirect pathway.
Projects to subthalamic nucleus, globus pallidus internus, and substantia nigra pars reticulata.

12.name: Internal Segment of Globus Pallidus
12.description: Medial output nucleus of the basal ganglia that gates thalamocortical drive to premotor and motor areas.
functions: Provides tonic inhibitory control over motor thalamus to regulate movement initiation.
Encodes movement parameters for learned motor sequences.
connections: Receives direct pathway input from striatum and excitatory drive from subthalamic nucleus.
Projects via the ansa lenticularis and lenticular fasciculus to ventral anterior and ventrolateral thalamic nuclei.

13.name: Claustrum
13.description: Thin telencephalic gray matter sheet between insula and putamen; highly connected with widespread cortical areas.
functions: Facilitates multimodal integration and attention switching across cortical networks.
connections: Reciprocally connected with widespread neocortex; links to limbic structures have been reported.

14.name: Basal Forebrain
14.description: Heterogeneous basal forebrain complex (nucleus basalis, diagonal band, medial septal nuclei) providing widespread cholinergic input.
functions: Supports attention, arousal, and learning through cortical acetylcholine release.
Modulates hippocampal plasticity underlying memory encoding.
connections: Receives input from limbic structures such as amygdala and prefrontal cortex.
Projects diffusely to neocortex, hippocampus, and amygdaloid complex.

15.name: Septal Nuclei
15.description: Basal forebrain nuclei coordinating hippocampal theta and autonomic responses.
functions: Drive hippocampal oscillations important for memory and navigation.
Integrate limbic inputs to regulate reward, motivation, and autonomic tone.
connections: Receive afferents from hippocampus, amygdala, and hypothalamus via the fornix.
Project via the medial forebrain bundle and fornix to hippocampus and hypothalamus.

16.name: Amygdaloid Complex
16.description: Hub for processing emotional salience and associative memory.

17.name: Anterior Amygdaloid Area
17.description: Rostral amygdalar subdivision interfacing olfactory, cortical, and basal forebrain inputs to shape emotional salience.
functions: Integrates olfactory cues with affective context for social and reproductive behaviors.
Provides modulatory output to basal forebrain cholinergic neurons.
connections: Receives projections from olfactory bulb, piriform cortex, and hippocampal formation.
Projects to medial amygdaloid nuclei, hypothalamus, and septal region.

18.name: Central Nuclear Group
18.description: Amygdalar core comprising the central nucleus that orchestrates autonomic and behavioral expressions of emotion.
functions: Coordinates defensive reactions and conditioned fear responses.
Regulates autonomic output via projections to hypothalamic and brainstem centers.
connections: Receives convergent input from basolateral amygdala and brainstem sensory relays.
Projects to hypothalamus, periaqueductal gray, parabrachial nucleus, and brainstem autonomic nuclei.

19.name: Lateral Nucleus
19.description: Principal sensory gateway of the amygdala processing multimodal inputs relevant to emotional learning.
functions: Encodes associative fear memories by integrating cortical and thalamic sensory signals.
Supports evaluation of stimulus salience for emotional decision making.
connections: Receives auditory and visual inputs from sensory thalamus and temporal cortex.
Projects to basolateral and central amygdalar nuclei for output to hypothalamic-brainstem effectors.

20.name: Basolateral Nucleus
20.description: Part of the basolateral complex supporting emotional learning.

21.name: Basomedial Nucleus
21.description: Transitional amygdalar nucleus linking olfactory and visceral information streams.

22.name: Anterior Cortical Nucleus
22.description: Olfactory-related amygdalar cortex involved in odor-guided behaviors and autonomic regulation.
functions: Links olfactory cues to reproductive and defensive behaviors.
Modulates autonomic responses tied to odor perception.
connections: Receives afferents from olfactory bulb, piriform cortex, and lateral olfactory tract.
Projects to medial amygdala, hypothalamic preoptic, and ventromedial nuclei.

23.name: Posterior Cortical Nucleus
23.description: Posterior cortical amygdalar subdivision bridging olfactory and hippocampal circuits for contextual odor memory.
functions: Supports contextual processing of olfactory cues and social odors.
Interfaces with hippocampus for odor-guided spatial memory.
connections: Receives input from olfactory bulb, entorhinal cortex, and piriform cortex.
Projects to hippocampal subiculum, medial amygdala, and hypothalamic targets.

24.name: Medial Nucleus
24.description: Medial amygdaloid nucleus specialized for chemosensory processing and reproductive behaviors.
functions: Interprets pheromonal information to regulate social and mating behaviors.
Influences hypothalamic autonomic and endocrine responses to olfactory cues.
connections: Receives accessory olfactory bulb and vomeronasal inputs via the stria terminalis.
Projects to bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, hypothalamus, and brainstem autonomic centers.

25.name: Amygdalohippocampal Area
25.description: Interface between amygdala and hippocampal formation.

26.name: Bed Nucleus of Stria Terminalis
26.description: Extended amygdala structure mediating sustained fear, stress responses, and neuroendocrine regulation.
aliases: Bed Nucleus of the Terminal Stria
functions: Integrates limbic information to modulate hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activity.
Supports anxiety-related vigilance and social behavior modulation.
connections: Receives input from amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex via stria terminalis.
Projects to hypothalamus, brainstem autonomic nuclei, and ventral tegmental area.

27.name: Thalamus
27.description: Relay hub of the diencephalon that channels sensory, motor, and limbic information to the cerebral cortex.
functions: Filters and routes ascending sensory signals to specific cortical targets.
Participates in cortico-thalamo-cortical loops supporting attention, sleep, and consciousness.
connections: Receives inputs from spinal, brainstem, basal ganglia, and cerebellar pathways.
Projects via thalamocortical radiations to virtually all cortical areas.

28.name: Anterior Nuclear Group of Thalamus
28.description: Anterior thalamic nuclei cluster critical for memory and spatial navigation via Papez circuit.
functions: Transmit hippocampal and mammillary body signals for episodic memory processing.
Contribute to head-direction signaling and spatial orientation.
connections: Receive mammillothalamic tract input from mammillary bodies and hippocampal fornix fibers.
Project to cingulate gyrus and retrosplenial cortex.

29.name: Lateral Dorsal Nucleus of Thalamus
29.description: Thalamic relay linking hippocampal circuits with cingulate cortex for visuospatial memory.
functions: Supports visuospatial attention and memory consolidation.
Integrates hippocampal and parietal inputs for navigation.
connections: Receives input from hippocampal subiculum and retrosplenial cortex.
Projects predominantly to cingulate cortex and parietal association areas.

30.name: Mediodorsal Nucleus of Thalamus
30.description: Association thalamic nucleus connecting prefrontal cortex with limbic and basal ganglia networks.
functions: Facilitates working memory, decision making, and reward-guided behavior.
Integrates limbic signals into prefrontal executive circuits.
connections: Receives afferents from amygdala, basal ganglia, and olfactory cortex.
Projects heavily to prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex.

31.name: Reuniens Nucleus of Thalamus
31.description: Midline thalamic nucleus coordinating hippocampal-prefrontal synchrony for memory consolidation.
functions: Synchronizes hippocampal theta activity with medial prefrontal cortex during memory tasks.
Supports retrieval and extinction of contextual fear memories.
connections: Receives hippocampal, amygdalar, and brainstem reticular inputs.
Projects to medial prefrontal cortex, hippocampal CA1, and subiculum.

32.name: Lateral Posterior Nucleus (LP)
32.description: Higher-order thalamic nucleus in rodents, homologous to pulvinar in primates; involved in visual processing and cortico-thalamic relay.
functions: Mediates attention shifts and integration of visual-somatosensory information.
Supports higher-order perceptual processing in parietal association cortex.
Mediates visual spatial attention and integration of visual information.
Acts as a relay between superior colliculus and visual association cortex.
connections: Interconnected with multiple visual association areas; in rodents, LP is pulvinar homolog.
Inputs from superior colliculus.
Outputs to visual association areas and parietal cortex.

33.name: Pulvinar of Thalamus
33.description: Large posterior thalamic nucleus subdivided into medial, lateral, inferior, and anterior regions; key in higher-order visual attention and cortico-cortical communication.
functions: Supports visual attention, salience detection, and integration of multimodal sensory inputs.
Facilitates cortico-thalamo-cortical communication between parietal, temporal, and frontal association cortices.
connections: Reciprocally connected with parietal, temporal, and frontal association cortices.
Inputs from superior colliculus; outputs to multiple association cortices.

34.name: Ventral Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
34.description: Motor thalamic nucleus transmitting basal ganglia output to frontal motor areas.
functions: Facilitates planning and initiation of voluntary movements.
Integrates cerebellar and basal ganglia signals for motor set maintenance.
Relays basal ganglia signals to premotor cortex.
Involved in motor planning and initiation.
connections: Receives input from globus pallidus internus and substantia nigra pars reticulata.
Projects to premotor cortex, supplementary motor area, and frontal eye fields.
Inputs from globus pallidus.
Outputs to premotor and supplementary motor areas.

35.name: Ventral Lateral Nucleus of Thalamus
35.description: Motor thalamic relay nucleus transmitting cerebellar and basal ganglia output to motor cortex.
functions: Supports voluntary movement planning and execution.
Integrates cerebellar timing signals with basal ganglia output.
Integrates cerebellar and basal ganglia signals for fine motor control.
Contributes to voluntary motor coordination.
connections: Receives input from the dentate nucleus of the cerebellum.
Receives basal ganglia projections from the globus pallidus internus.
Projects to primary motor and premotor cortical areas.
Inputs from cerebellum and globus pallidus.
Outputs to primary motor and premotor cortex.

36.name: Ventral Posterior Lateral Nucleus
36.description: Somatosensory relay conveying body tactile and proprioceptive information to primary somatosensory cortex.
functions: Transmits discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception from trunk and limbs.
Participates in pain and temperature processing via spinothalamic pathways.
connections: Receives lemniscal inputs from medial lemniscus and spinothalamic tract.
Projects to postcentral gyrus and secondary somatosensory cortex.

37.name: Ventral Posterior Medial Nucleus
37.description: Thalamic relay for trigeminal somatosensory information targeting face representation in cortex.
functions: Conveys facial touch, taste, and nociceptive signals to the primary somatosensory cortex.
Supports gustatory processing through its parvicellular subdivision.
connections: Receives trigeminothalamic and gustatory inputs from brainstem nuclei.
Projects to face area of postcentral gyrus and insular gustatory cortex.

38.name: Dorsal Lateral Geniculate Nucleus
38.description: Primary visual thalamic relay transmitting retinal input to the visual cortex.
functions: Processes spatial and chromatic features for conscious vision.
Maintains retinotopic maps and regulates visual attention via corticothalamic feedback.
connections: Receives retinal ganglion cell axons via the optic tract.
Projects through optic radiations to primary visual cortex (V1).

39.name: Medial Geniculate Nuclei
39.description: Auditory thalamic nuclei relaying sound frequency and localization cues to auditory cortex.
functions: Transforms auditory brainstem inputs into cortical receptive field properties.
Supports auditory attention and sound localization.
connections: Receives ascending inputs from inferior colliculus and auditory brainstem nuclei.
Projects to primary and secondary auditory cortices in the temporal lobe.

40.name: Centromedian Nucleus of Thalamus
40.description: Intralaminar thalamic nucleus involved in arousal, nociception, and basal ganglia communication.
functions: Modulates attention and sensorimotor gating within basal ganglia loops.
Participates in pain processing and arousal regulation.
connections: Receives inputs from spinothalamic tract, reticular formation, and globus pallidus internus.
Projects to striatum, supplementary motor area, and widespread cortex via intralaminar projections.

41.name: Parafascicular Nucleus of Thalamus
41.description: Intralaminar thalamic partner of the centromedian nucleus that influences associative learning and nociception.
functions: Supports cognitive flexibility and action selection within basal ganglia circuits.
Contributes to pain perception and autonomic responses.
connections: Receives inputs from spinoreticular and cerebellar pathways.
Projects densely to striatal matrix and limbic cortex.

42.name: Habenular Nuclei
42.description: Epithalamic relay shaping reward and aversion signaling.

43.name: Pineal Body
43.description: Midline neuroendocrine gland that secretes melatonin to entrain circadian rhythms.
functions: Synthesizes melatonin to regulate sleep-wake cycles and seasonal physiology.
Modulates hypothalamic and pituitary hormone release.
connections: Receives sympathetic innervation via the superior cervical ganglion and paraventricular hypothalamus.
Projects hormonal signals into cerebrospinal fluid and systemic circulation.

44.name: Zona Incerta
44.description: Subthalamic gray zone participating in sensorimotor integration and arousal modulation.
functions: Influences somatosensory processing, eye movements, and arousal state.
Contributes to limbic-motor coordination for feeding and defensive behaviors.
connections: Receives inputs from motor cortex, cerebellum, and basal ganglia structures.
Projects to thalamic nuclei, superior colliculus, spinal cord, and brainstem reticular formation.

45.name: Subthalamic Nucleus
45.description: Lentiform subthalamic nucleus essential for indirect basal ganglia pathway control of movement.
functions: Provides excitatory drive to globus pallidus internus to suppress unwanted movements.
Participates in decision thresholds for action selection.
connections: Receives inhibitory input from globus pallidus externus and excitatory cortical afferents.
Projects to globus pallidus internus, substantia nigra pars reticulata, and pedunculopontine nucleus.

46.name: Hypothalamus
46.description: Controls autonomic, endocrine, and behavioral homeostasis.

47.name: Preoptic Region of Hypothalamus
47.description: Anterior hypothalamic sector regulating reproductive behaviors, thermoregulation, and circadian rhythms.
functions: Controls gonadotropin release and sexual behaviors via GnRH neurons.
Monitors core temperature and initiates heat-loss mechanisms.
connections: Receives inputs from limbic forebrain, retina, and brainstem thermoregulatory centers.
Projects to pituitary gland, autonomic brainstem nuclei, and other hypothalamic regions.

48.name: Supraoptic Region of Hypothalamus
48.description: Hypothalamic division housing magnocellular neurons that release vasopressin and oxytocin.
functions: Regulates water balance through vasopressin secretion.
Controls parturition and lactation via oxytocin release.
connections: Receives osmotic and cardiovascular sensory inputs from circumventricular organs and brainstem.
Projects neurosecretory axons to posterior pituitary and parvocellular projections to autonomic centers.

49.name: Tuberal Region of Hypothalamus
49.description: Mid-hypothalamic zone containing ventromedial and dorsomedial nuclei for energy balance and circadian rhythms.
functions: Regulates feeding, metabolism, and satiety signaling.
Coordinates circadian output via the suprachiasmatic nucleus connections.
connections: Receives inputs from arcuate nucleus, brainstem visceral centers, and limbic cortex.
Projects to autonomic brainstem nuclei, pituitary, and widespread hypothalamic targets.

50.name: Mammillary Region of Hypothalamus
50.description: Posterior hypothalamic region centered on mammillary bodies that supports memory and spatial navigation.
functions: Participates in recollective memory through the Papez circuit.
Integrates vestibular and head-direction signals for navigation.
connections: Receives hippocampal inputs via the fornix.
Projects through the mammillothalamic and mammillotegmental tracts to thalamus and midbrain.

51.name: White Matter of Forebrain
51.description: Major myelinated fiber systems of the forebrain enabling long-range communication between cortical and subcortical regions.
functions: Supports efficient transmission of sensory, motor, and associative information across hemispheres and lobes.
Provides structural scaffolding for cortico-cortical and cortico-subcortical loops.
connections: Includes commissural tracts, association fibers, and projection pathways.
Links cortical areas with thalamus, basal ganglia, hippocampus, and brainstem.

52.name: Anterior Commissure
52.description: Compact commissural tract connecting temporal lobes and olfactory structures across hemispheres.
functions: Interhemispheric communication between anterior temporal lobes and amygdalae.
Carries olfactory interconnections between hemispheres.
connections: Interconnects anterior temporal cortices, amygdalae, and olfactory bulbs.
Links orbitofrontal and inferior frontal regions across the midline.

53.name: Corpus Callosum
53.description: Largest cerebral commissure enabling integration of sensory, motor, and cognitive functions between hemispheres.
functions: Coordinates bilateral cortical processing for language, vision, and motor control.
Facilitates interhemispheric transfer of learning and memory representations.
connections: Contains callosal fibers linking homologous neocortical areas across frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
Connects cingulate cortices via the forceps minor and major.

54.name: Fornix
54.description: C-shaped fiber bundle connecting hippocampus to mammillary bodies and septal area.
functions: Supports memory consolidation and retrieval within the Papez circuit.
Transmits hippocampal signals controlling hypothalamic autonomic responses.
connections: Arises from hippocampal fimbria and subiculum.
Projects to mammillary bodies, septal nuclei, and anterior thalamic nuclei.

55.name: Mammillothalamic Tract
55.description: White matter tract linking mammillary bodies to anterior thalamic nuclei within the Papez circuit.
functions: Conveys mnemonic information from hypothalamus to thalamus for cingulate processing.
Supports spatial orientation and episodic memory.
connections: Originates in mammillary bodies of the hypothalamus.
Terminates in anterior thalamic nuclei projecting to cingulate cortex.

56.name: Optic Tract
56.description: Axonal continuation of the optic nerve carrying retinal signals to thalamic and midbrain visual centers.
functions: Relays visual information for conscious perception, reflexes, and circadian entrainment.
Supports pupillary light reflex via pretectal projections.
connections: Receives input from retinal ganglion cell axons after optic chiasm.
Projects to lateral geniculate nucleus, superior colliculus, pretectum, and suprachiasmatic nucleus.

57.name: Anterior Horn of Lateral Ventricle
57.description: Frontal extension of the lateral ventricle that cushions frontal lobe structures with cerebrospinal fluid.
functions: Provides CSF circulation and homeostasis for frontal cerebral tissues.
Acts as anatomical landmark during neurosurgical navigation.
connections: Continuous with the ventricular body at the foramen of Monro.
Communicates CSF flow with third ventricle via interventricular foramen.

58.name: Body of Lateral Ventricle
58.description: Central segment of the lateral ventricle running through parietal lobe white matter.
functions: Maintains cerebrospinal fluid reservoir for parietal and callosal structures.
Supports nutrient exchange and waste clearance through ependymal lining.
connections: Connects anterior and posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.
Communicates with choroid plexus for CSF production.

59.name: Posterior Horn of Lateral Ventricle
59.description: Occipital recess of the lateral ventricle extending into the occipital lobe.
functions: Provides CSF support to visual association cortex.
Serves as radiologic landmark for optic radiations.
connections: Continuous with ventricular atrium near the splenium of the corpus callosum.
Contains choroid plexus continuation into the temporal horn.

60.name: Inferior Horn of Lateral Ventricle
60.description: Temporal extension of the lateral ventricle adjacent to hippocampus and amygdala.
functions: Supports CSF circulation near hippocampal formation.
Provides surgical corridor for medial temporal lobe procedures.
connections: Extends from ventricular atrium alongside hippocampal head and tail.
Contains choroid plexus and collateral eminence landmarks.

61.name: Third Ventricle
61.description: Midline ventricular cavity of the diencephalon connecting lateral and fourth ventricles.
functions: Ensures cerebrospinal fluid circulation between forebrain and brainstem.
Provides ependymal interface for hypothalamic hormone diffusion.
connections: Receives CSF from lateral ventricles via foramina of Monro.
Drains into cerebral aqueduct leading to fourth ventricle.

62.name: Cerebellar Vermis
62.description: Midline cerebellar structure coordinating axial posture.

63.name: Cerebellar Deep Nuclei
63.description: Deep cerebellar nuclei that serve as primary output channels from cerebellar cortex.
functions: Transform cerebellar cortical computations into motor and cognitive commands.
Contribute to balance, eye movements, and limb coordination.
connections: Receive inhibitory Purkinje cell projections from cerebellar cortex.
Project via superior cerebellar peduncle to red nucleus, thalamus, and vestibular nuclei.

64.name: White Matter of Hindbrain
64.description: Myelinated fiber tracts of the hindbrain conveying sensory, motor, and autonomic information.
functions: Provide conduits between spinal cord, cerebellum, and higher brain centers.
Support brainstem reflex arcs and cranial nerve pathways.
connections: Includes ascending sensory tracts and descending corticospinal and corticonuclear fibers.
Links brainstem nuclei with cerebellum via cerebellar peduncles.

65.name: Olfactory Tract
65.description: Bundle of olfactory bulb axons transmitting odor information to olfactory cortex and limbic structures.
functions: Conveys processed olfactory signals for conscious perception and emotional associations.
Supports odor-guided behaviors through projections to limbic areas.
connections: Originates from mitral and tufted cells of the olfactory bulb.
Projects to piriform cortex, olfactory tubercle, amygdala, and entorhinal cortex.

66.name: Precentral Gyrus
66.description: Primary motor cortex gyrus containing the somatotopic map for voluntary movements.
functions: Generates corticospinal commands for skilled limb and facial movements.
Encodes force and direction parameters of motor output.
connections: Receives input from premotor, supplementary motor, and somatosensory cortices.
Projects via corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts to spinal and brainstem motor nuclei.

67.name: Superior Frontal Gyrus
67.description: Dorsal frontal lobe gyrus involved in executive control, working memory, and self-referential processing.
functions: Supports planning, attention shifting, and motor imagery.
Contributes to default mode network activity related to introspection.
connections: Interconnects with dorsolateral prefrontal, parietal, and cingulate cortices.
Projects to caudate nucleus and thalamic mediodorsal nucleus.

68.name: Middle Frontal Gyrus
68.description: Central frontal gyrus mediating executive functions, language, and eye movement planning.
functions: Facilitates working memory, attentional control, and reasoning.
Supports language production via dorsolateral prefrontal circuits.
connections: Receives multimodal input from parietal association areas and thalamus.
Projects to caudate nucleus, premotor cortex, and inferior frontal regions.

69.name: Triangular Inferior Frontal Gyrus
69.description: Frontal language region involved in expressive and semantic aspects of speech.
functions: Supports semantic selection and controlled language production.
Contributes to syntactic processing during speech planning.
connections: Interacts with the superior temporal gyrus via the arcuate fasciculus.
Connects with dorsolateral prefrontal and supplementary motor areas.

70.name: Opercular Inferior Frontal Gyrus
70.description: Inferior frontal opercular subdivision implicated in language articulation and sensorimotor integration.
aliases: Opercular Part of Inferior Frontal Gyrus
functions: Coordinates speech production and phonological processing.
Integrates orofacial motor commands with auditory feedback.
connections: Receives input from superior temporal auditory areas and premotor cortex.
Projects to motor cortex, basal ganglia, and supplementary motor area.

71.name: Gyrus Rectus (Straight Gyrus)
71.description: Medial orbital gyrus anterior to olfactory sulcus involved in reward valuation and autonomic control.
functions: Evaluates reward contingencies and social cues.
Regulates autonomic responses tied to emotion.
connections: Connected with orbitofrontal cortex, amygdala, and hypothalamus.
Receives olfactory input via anterior olfactory nucleus and piriform cortex.

72.name: Medial Orbital Gyrus
72.description: Medial orbital surface gyrus integrating reward, emotion, and visceral information.
functions: Participates in valuation-based decision making.
Modulates autonomic responses and affective states.
connections: Interconnects with ventromedial prefrontal cortex, amygdala, and hippocampus.
Projects to hypothalamus and ventral striatum.

73.name: Anterior Orbital Gyrus
73.description: Anterior orbital gyrus bridging medial and lateral orbital surfaces for social-emotional appraisal.
functions: Assesses reward expectations and emotional significance of stimuli.
Supports adaptive decision making in complex social contexts.
connections: Receives input from amygdala, temporal pole, and sensory association cortices.
Projects to ventromedial prefrontal and striatal circuits.

74.name: Posterior Orbital Gyrus
74.description: Posterior intermediate orbital gyrus contributing to taste, olfaction, and reward-guided behavior.
functions: Integrates gustatory and olfactory cues with reward value.
Participates in reversal learning and adaptive control.
connections: Connected with insular cortex, gustatory thalamus, and amygdala.
Projects to ventral striatum and medial prefrontal cortex.

75.name: Lateral Orbital Gyrus
75.description: Lateral orbital gyrus interfacing sensory association inputs with reward-based decision circuits.
functions: Supports evaluation of punishers and behavioral change.
Integrates multisensory evidence for value-based choices.
connections: Receives projections from temporal association cortex, amygdala, and sensory cortices.
Projects to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, striatum, and hypothalamus.

76.name: Rostral Paracentral Lobule
76.description: Medial frontal lobule housing supplementary motor areas for leg and trunk representation.
functions: Initiates internally driven movements and bimanual coordination.
Participates in motor planning for locomotion.
connections: Receives inputs from premotor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
Projects to corticospinal tract targeting lower limb motor neurons.

77.name: Frontal Operculum
77.description: Portion of inferior frontal cortex forming operculum over insula, central to gustatory and language functions.
functions: Processes taste perception and orofacial somatosensation.
Contributes to articulation planning and phonological working memory.
connections: Receives gustatory thalamic input and insular projections.
Projects to motor cortex, ventral striatum, and anterior insula.

78.name: Postcentral Gyrus
78.description: Primary somatosensory cortex gyrus encoding tactile and proprioceptive information.
functions: Maps somatotopic sensory input for conscious perception of touch, vibration, and proprioception.
Supports sensorimotor integration for fine motor control.
connections: Receives thalamic input from VPL and VPM nuclei.
Projects to secondary somatosensory cortex, posterior parietal cortex, and motor areas.

79.name: Superior Parietal Lobule
79.description: Dorsal parietal lobule involved in visuomotor coordination, spatial attention, and reaching.
functions: Integrates somatosensory and visual information for spatial representation.
Guides hand-eye coordination and body awareness.
connections: Interconnects with premotor cortex, superior occipital cortex, and cerebellum.
Projects to intraparietal sulcus regions and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

80.name: Supramarginal Gyrus
80.description: Inferior parietal gyrus supporting language, empathy, and multimodal integration.
functions: Facilitates phonological processing and verbal working memory.
Contributes to theory of mind and body schema.
connections: Receives inputs from auditory cortex, somatosensory cortex, and visual association areas.
Projects to inferior frontal gyrus, premotor cortex, and temporoparietal junction.

81.name: Angular Gyrus
81.description: Posterior inferior parietal gyrus integrating visual, auditory, and somatosensory cues for language and spatial cognition.
functions: Supports semantic processing, reading, and number cognition.
Mediates attention reorienting and spatial awareness.
connections: Interconnects with temporal association cortex, prefrontal regions, and hippocampal formation.
Projects to default mode network hubs and language networks.

82.name: Precuneus
82.description: Medial parietal cortex involved in visuospatial imagery, self-referential thought, and memory retrieval.
functions: Supports episodic memory and scene construction.
Participates in default mode network and conscious awareness.
connections: Receives input from posterior cingulate, parietal, and occipital cortices.
Projects to medial prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, and thalamus.

83.name: Caudal Paracentral Lobule
83.description: Posterior continuation of paracentral lobule containing somatotopic representation of lower limbs in somatosensory cortex.
functions: Processes sensory feedback from legs and pelvic region.
Contributes to proprioceptive control of gait.
connections: Receives thalamic VPL input for lower limb sensory modalities.
Projects to supplementary motor and premotor areas for locomotor control.

84.name: Superior Temporal Gyrus
84.description: Dorsal temporal gyrus specialized for auditory processing and language comprehension.
functions: Processes primary auditory information including pitch and speech perception.
Supports social cognition via superior temporal sulcus regions.
connections: Receives input from medial geniculate nucleus and auditory brainstem pathways.
Projects to inferior frontal gyrus, parietal association cortex, and limbic areas.

85.name: Middle Temporal Gyrus
85.description: Middle temporal gyrus involved in semantic memory, language comprehension, and motion perception.
functions: Supports lexical retrieval and conceptual knowledge.
Participates in processing visual motion and biological movement.
connections: Interconnects with inferior frontal language areas, angular gyrus, and temporal pole.
Projects to ventral visual stream and limbic cortices.

86.name: Inferior Temporal Gyrus
86.description: Inferior temporal gyrus forming part of ventral visual stream for object recognition.
functions: Encodes complex visual features for object and face recognition.
Supports semantic categorization and memory recall.
connections: Receives input from occipital visual areas and superior temporal sulcus.
Projects to perirhinal cortex, amygdala, and prefrontal cortex.

87.name: Temporal Fusiform Gyrus
87.description: Ventral temporal gyrus specialized for high-level visual processing including face and word recognition.
functions: Supports fusiform face area and visual word form area for expert pattern recognition.
Integrates visual identity cues with memory and emotion.
connections: Receives input from ventral visual stream and occipital cortex.
Projects to inferior temporal, parahippocampal, and prefrontal areas.

88.name: Transverse Temporal Gyrus
88.description: Heschl's gyrus forming primary auditory cortex receiving tonotopic thalamic input.
functions: Processes fundamental acoustic features such as frequency, intensity, and timing.
Initiates cortical analysis for speech and music perception.
connections: Receives thalamocortical projections from medial geniculate nucleus.
Projects to surrounding auditory association cortices and insula.

89.name: Planum Temporale
89.description: Planum posterior to Heschl's gyrus involved in auditory spatial processing and language lateralization.
functions: Supports integration of auditory spatial cues and speech perception.
Contributes to phonological working memory and language dominance.
connections: Interacts with superior temporal gyrus, inferior parietal lobule, and frontal operculum.
Receives projections from auditory association cortex and medial geniculate body.

90.name: Temporal Pole
90.description: Anterior temporal lobe apex integrating multimodal sensory and limbic inputs for social and semantic processing.
functions: Mediates social-emotional cognition and autobiographical memory.
Supports semantic representations of people and objects.
connections: Receives afferents from amygdala, orbitofrontal cortex, and sensory association cortices.
Projects to limbic structures, insula, and prefrontal cortex.

91.name: Planum Polare
91.description: Anterior superior temporal plane region processing complex auditory patterns and prosody.
functions: Analyzes spectral aspects of speech and music.
Participates in auditory attention and predictive coding.
connections: Receives input from primary auditory cortex and medial geniculate nucleus.
Projects to superior temporal gyrus, inferior frontal cortex, and insula.

92.name: Occipital Pole
92.description: Posterior-most occipital lobe region containing primary visual cortex representations.
functions: Supports high-acuity vision and processing of central visual field.
Integrates binocular input for depth perception.
connections: Receives afferents via optic radiations from lateral geniculate nucleus.
Projects to surrounding visual association cortices and splenial callosal fibers.

93.name: Cuneus
93.description: Medial occipital gyrus forming part of primary visual cortex and dorsal visual stream.
functions: Processes lower visual field information and motion cues.
Supports visuospatial attention via dorsal stream pathways.
connections: Receives input from lateral geniculate nucleus via optic radiations.
Projects to superior parietal lobule and other occipital areas.

94.name: Lingual Gyrus
94.description: Medial occipitotemporal gyrus critical for visual memory and recognition of complex scenes.
functions: Participates in encoding of letters, words, and visual imagery.
Supports processing of visual scenes and dream imagery.
connections: Interconnects with calcarine cortex, parahippocampal gyrus, and fusiform gyrus.
Projects to hippocampus and cingulate cortex via posterior cingulum.

95.name: Occipital Fusiform Gyrus
95.description: Ventral occipital gyrus serving as part of the ventral visual stream for object and face processing.
functions: Integrates shape, color, and texture information for recognition.
Supports reading and orthographic processing.
connections: Receives projections from calcarine cortex and lateral occipital complex.
Projects to inferior temporal cortex and limbic structures.

96.name: Inferior Occipital Gyrus
96.description: Inferolateral occipital gyrus contributing to visual motion and object recognition pathways.
functions: Participates in processing complex object shapes and motion cues.
Supports integration of visual and spatial information for perception.
connections: Receives input from primary visual cortex and lateral occipital areas.
Projects to temporal visual association cortices and parietal regions.

97.name: Superior Occipital Gyrus
97.description: Dorsal occipital region that participates in spatial and motion aspects of vision.
functions: Processes visuospatial information for the dorsal visual stream.
Integrates motion cues with parietal attention networks.
connections: Links to parietal cortices through the dorsal visual pathway.
Interconnects with middle occipital gyrus and intraparietal sulcus.

98.name: Anterior Cingulate Gyrus
98.description: Medial frontal gyrus implicated in cognitive control, emotion regulation, and autonomic integration.
functions: Monitors conflict and error to adjust behavior.
Integrates emotion and motivation with decision making.
connections: Receives input from prefrontal cortex, amygdala, and thalamus.
Projects to premotor cortex, autonomic brainstem nuclei, and limbic structures.

99.name: Posterior Cingulate Gyrus
99.description: Posterior cingulate gyrus serving as a default mode network hub for memory and self-processing.
functions: Supports episodic memory retrieval and spatial orientation.
Integrates internal mentation with environmental awareness.
connections: Interconnects with precuneus, medial temporal lobe, and medial prefrontal cortex.
Receives thalamic inputs from anterior nuclei and projects via cingulum bundle.

100.name: Cingulo-Parahippocampal Isthmus
100.description: Narrow bridge linking cingulate and parahippocampal gyri carrying fibers of the cingulum bundle.
functions: Integrates retrosplenial and parahippocampal processing for memory and navigation.
Supports limbic connectivity between posterior cingulate and hippocampal formation.
connections: Contains cingulum fibers connecting posterior cingulate to parahippocampal regions.
Links retrosplenial cortex with hippocampus and entorhinal cortex.

101.name: Subcallosal (Parolfactory) Gyrus
101.description: Small medial frontal gyrus adjacent to corpus callosum involved in reward, olfaction, and limbic processing.
functions: Regulates mood and autonomic responses via limbic circuits.
Participates in olfactory-driven emotional processing.
connections: Receives inputs from orbitofrontal cortex, amygdala, and olfactory structures.
Projects to hypothalamus, ventral striatum, and cingulate cortex.

102.name: Anterior Parahippocampal Gyrus
102.description: Anterior segment of parahippocampal gyrus associated with entorhinal cortex and olfactory-limbic integration.
functions: Supports encoding of contextual and episodic memories.
Integrates olfactory inputs with hippocampal memory circuits.
connections: Receives input from entorhinal, perirhinal, and olfactory cortices.
Projects to hippocampal formation, amygdala, and orbitofrontal cortex.

103.name: Posterior Parahippocampal Gyrus
103.description: Posterior parahippocampal gyrus encompassing parahippocampal place area for scene perception.
functions: Processes spatial layouts and environmental scenes.
Supports memory for locations and contextual associations.
connections: Receives input from retrosplenial cortex, occipital visual areas, and hippocampus.
Projects to entorhinal cortex, cingulate gyrus, and medial temporal lobe.

104.name: Ambiens Gyrus
104.description: Medial temporal gyrus adjacent to hippocampus contributing to olfactory and memory integration.
functions: Supports odor-based memory and emotional responses.
Links olfactory information with hippocampal encoding.
connections: Receives input from olfactory cortex and amygdala.
Projects to entorhinal cortex, hippocampus, and hypothalamus.

105.name: Head of Hippocampus
105.description: Telencephalic structure with dentate gyrus, CA fields, and subiculum; essential for episodic memory, navigation, and contextual learning.
functions: Encodes episodic memories with strong affective components.
Participates in hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis modulation.
Encodes and retrieves episodic and spatial memory.
Supports spatial navigation via place cells and cognitive maps.
connections: Receives entorhinal and amygdalar inputs via perforant pathway.
Projects to fornix, septal nuclei, and hypothalamus.
Inputs from entorhinal cortex via perforant path.
Outputs through subiculum and fornix to mammillary bodies and prefrontal cortex.

106.name: Body of Hippocampus
106.description: Telencephalic structure with dentate gyrus, CA fields, and subiculum; essential for episodic memory, navigation, and contextual learning.
functions: Supports spatial navigation and associative memory.
Mediates communication between anterior and posterior hippocampal segments.
Encodes and retrieves episodic and spatial memory.
Supports spatial navigation via place cells and cognitive maps.
connections: Receives perforant pathway input from entorhinal cortex and septal modulation.
Projects along longitudinal fibers to fornix and subiculum.
Inputs from entorhinal cortex via perforant path.
Outputs through subiculum and fornix to mammillary bodies and prefrontal cortex.

107.name: Tail of Hippocampus
107.description: Telencephalic structure with dentate gyrus, CA fields, and subiculum; essential for episodic memory, navigation, and contextual learning.
functions: Supports precise spatial mapping and scene discrimination.
Contributes to memory retrieval and navigation planning.
Encodes and retrieves episodic and spatial memory.
Supports spatial navigation via place cells and cognitive maps.
connections: Receives input from retrosplenial cortex and entorhinal posterior regions.
Projects via fornix and subiculum to thalamus and mammillary bodies.
Inputs from entorhinal cortex via perforant path.
Outputs through subiculum and fornix to mammillary bodies and prefrontal cortex.

108.name: Long Insular Gyri
108.description: Long gyri on insular surface processing visceral sensation and interoceptive awareness.
functions: Encode pain, temperature, and vestibular signals.
Support integration of bodily states with emotional awareness.
connections: Receive inputs from thalamic ventromedial posterior nucleus and somatosensory cortices.
Project to anterior insula, cingulate cortex, and prefrontal regions.

109.name: Short Insular Gyri
109.description: Short anterior insular gyri responsible for higher-order interoception, emotion, and gustation.
functions: Facilitate awareness of emotions and bodily feelings.
Participate in taste processing and autonomic control.
connections: Receive input from thalamic gustatory nuclei, amygdala, and frontal operculum.
Project to anterior cingulate cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, and limbic structures.

110.name: Limen Insula
110.description: Transition zone between insula and temporal lobe that relays olfactory and gustatory signals.
functions: Integrates chemosensory inputs before distribution to insular and orbitofrontal cortices.
Coordinates visceral-autonomic responses to taste and smell.
connections: Receives fibers from olfactory tract and gustatory thalamus.
Projects to anterior insula, amygdala, and frontal operculum.

111.name: Pretectal Region
111.description: Dorsal midbrain region mediating pupillary reflexes and visual attention shifts.
functions: Controls pupillary light reflex and accommodation.
Contributes to visuomotor coordination for eye movements.
connections: Receives retinal and superior colliculus inputs via optic tract.
Projects to Edinger-Westphal nucleus, superior colliculus, and pulvinar.

112.name: Midbrain Tegmentum
112.description: Central midbrain region containing ascending arousal systems and cranial nerve nuclei.
functions: Maintains arousal and reward processing via dopaminergic and cholinergic neurons.
Integrates sensory information for orienting and reflexive responses.
connections: Receives inputs from cerebral cortex, cerebellum, and spinal cord.
Projects to thalamus, basal ganglia, hypothalamus, and spinal cord.

113.name: Red Nucleus
113.description: Paired midbrain nucleus coordinating motor learning and limb movement timing.
functions: Facilitates limb flexor control and motor learning.
Relays cerebellar output to spinal and cortical motor systems.
connections: Receives cerebellar dentate nucleus projections via superior cerebellar peduncle.
Projects to spinal cord via rubrospinal tract and to thalamus.

114.name: Substantia Nigra
114.description: Basal midbrain structure with dopaminergic and GABAergic subdivisions crucial for movement and reward.
functions: Regulates motor initiation through dopamine release to striatum.
Provides inhibitory output to thalamus and superior colliculus for eye movement control.
connections: Receives afferents from striatum and subthalamic nucleus.
Projects dopaminergic fibers to striatum and inhibitory projections to thalamus and brainstem.

115.name: Superior Colliculus
115.description: Layered midbrain tectal structure integrating visual signals for orienting movements.
functions: Coordinates saccadic eye movements and head orientation.
Integrates multimodal sensory cues for spatial attention.
connections: Receives retinal, cortical, and auditory inputs.
Projects to brainstem gaze centers, thalamus, and spinal cord.

116.name: Inferior Colliculus
116.description: Midbrain auditory tectal structure processing sound localization and reflexes.
functions: Integrates auditory signals from brainstem nuclei for spatial hearing.
Drives acoustic startle and orienting reflexes.
connections: Receives inputs from cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, and lateral lemniscus.
Projects to medial geniculate nucleus and auditory cortex.

117.name: Cerebral Peduncle (Crus Cerebri)
117.description: Massive descending fiber bundle conveying cortical motor signals through the midbrain.
functions: Transmits corticospinal, corticobulbar, and corticopontine fibers.
Supports voluntary movement control and cerebellar feedback loops.
connections: Receives axons from frontal, parietal, and temporal cortices.
Projects to brainstem motor nuclei, pontine nuclei, and spinal cord.

118.name: Superior Cerebellar Peduncle
118.description: Major efferent pathway from cerebellum carrying processed motor signals to brainstem and thalamus.
functions: Channels cerebellar output for motor coordination and eye movements.
Participates in cognitive loops linking cerebellum to frontal cortex.
connections: Receives input from dentate, interposed, and fastigial nuclei.
Projects to red nucleus, thalamus, and vestibular nuclei.

119.name: Cerebral Aqueduct
119.description: Narrow canal linking third and fourth ventricles through the midbrain.
functions: Allows cerebrospinal fluid flow from forebrain to hindbrain.
Helps distribute neuroendocrine signals within ventricular system.
connections: Connects third ventricle superiorly with fourth ventricle inferiorly.
Borders periaqueductal gray, facilitating diffusion of neuromodulators.

120.name: Paravermis of Cerebellum
120.description: Intermediate cerebellar zone between vermis and hemispheres coordinating limb and trunk movements.
functions: Adjusts ongoing limb movements and posture via spinocerebellar feedback.
Contributes to motor learning for reaching and grasping.
connections: Receives spinocerebellar and pontocerebellar inputs.
Projects to interposed nuclei and onward to red nucleus and motor cortex.

121.name: Lateral Hemisphere of Cerebellum
121.description: Lateral cerebellar hemispheres involved in planning complex movements and cognitive processing.
functions: Support motor planning, timing, and error correction.
Participate in language, working memory, and executive functions.
connections: Receive extensive pontocerebellar input from cerebral cortex.
Project via dentate nucleus to thalamus and prefrontal/motor areas.

122.name: Basilar Part of Pons
122.description: Basilar pons containing pontine nuclei and transverse fibers.

123.name: Pontine Tegmentum
123.description: Pontine tegmental core with cranial nerve nuclei.

124.name: Pyramidal Part of Medulla Oblongata
124.description: Anterior medullary pyramid containing corticospinal fibers descending to spinal cord.
functions: Convey voluntary motor commands from motor cortex to spinal motor neurons.
Participate in decussation controlling contralateral limb movements.
connections: Receive corticospinal axons from cerebral cortex.
Project to spinal cord anterior horn cells after pyramidal decussation.

125.name: Tegmentum of Medulla Oblongata
125.description: Medullary tegmentum housing autonomic nuclei, reticular formation, and cranial nerve centers.
functions: Regulates cardiovascular, respiratory, and reflex functions.
Integrates sensory input for arousal and motor coordination.
connections: Receives inputs from spinal cord, cerebellum, and cranial nerves.
Projects to hypothalamus, thalamus, and spinal cord.

126.name: Inferior Olive
126.description: Medullary olivary complex providing climbing fiber input to cerebellum for motor learning.
functions: Generates error signals that guide cerebellar plasticity.
Synchronizes motor timing and coordination.
connections: Receives input from cortex, spinal cord, and red nucleus.
Projects climbing fibers to contralateral cerebellar cortex.

127.name: Inferior Cerebellar Peduncle
127.description: Large fiber bundle carrying afferent inputs from spinal cord and medulla to cerebellum.
functions: Transmits proprioceptive and vestibular information to cerebellum.
Supports balance and posture adjustments.
connections: Receives dorsal spinocerebellar, vestibular, and olivocerebellar fibers.
Projects to cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei.

128.name: Middle Cerebellar Peduncle
128.description: Massive pontocerebellar pathway conveying cortical information into cerebellum.
functions: Carries pontine nuclei efferents encoding cortical motor plans.
Supports coordination of voluntary movements and cognitive timing.
connections: Receives pontocerebellar fibers originating from corticopontine inputs.
Projects to lateral cerebellar hemispheres.

129.name: Fourth Ventricle
129.description: Diamond-shaped ventricular cavity within pons and medulla containing cerebrospinal fluid.
functions: Circulates CSF between cerebral aqueduct and central canal/subarachnoid space.
Provides ependymal surface for neuroendocrine exchange.
connections: Receives CSF from cerebral aqueduct and lateral apertures.
Drains into central canal and subarachnoid cisterns via foramina of Magendie and Luschka.

130.name: Central Canal of Medulla Oblongata
130.description: Continuation of ventricular system through medulla into spinal cord.
functions: Conducts cerebrospinal fluid toward spinal cord.
Supports diffusion of neuromodulators within medullary gray.
connections: Continuous rostrally with fourth ventricle.
Extends caudally into spinal cord central canal.

131.name: Midline Nuclear Complex
131.description: Midline brainstem nuclei supporting arousal and visceral control.

132.name: Lateral Olfactory Gyrus
132.description: Olfactory cortical gyrus along medial frontal lobe receiving olfactory tract fibers.
functions: Participates in odor discrimination and associative olfactory learning.
Links olfactory perception with emotion and memory.
connections: Receives lateral olfactory tract projections from olfactory bulb.
Projects to piriform cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, and amygdala.

133.name: Parietal Operculum
133.description: Opercular parietal region overlying insula that contributes to somatosensory integration.
functions: Processes secondary somatosensory information including pain and temperature.
Integrates tactile input with gustatory and vestibular signals.
connections: Receives thalamic input from ventral posterior inferior and ventromedial nuclei.
Projects to insula, inferior parietal lobule, and premotor cortex.

134.name: Posteroventral Putamen
134.description: Ventral portion of putamen enriched in limbic and associative inputs.
functions: Integrates reward-related and sensorimotor signals for habit formation.
Supports action selection linked to motivational context.
connections: Receives inputs from orbitofrontal cortex, insula, and motor areas.
Projects to globus pallidus externus and ventral pallidum.

135.name: Paracingulate Gyrus
135.description: Medial frontal gyrus within cingulate sulcus involved in conflict monitoring and social cognition.
functions: Evaluates action outcomes and cognitive conflict.
Supports mentalizing and self-awareness.
connections: Receives input from prefrontal cortex, limbic structures, and thalamus.
Projects to supplementary motor area, striatum, and brainstem autonomic centers.

136.name: Rostral Gyrus
136.description: Medial frontal pole gyrus bordering cingulate sulcus involved in high-level executive and social cognition.
functions: Supports prospective memory and strategic planning.
Contributes to social inference and emotional regulation.
connections: Interconnects with ventromedial prefrontal cortex, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and anterior cingulate.
Projects to caudate nucleus, thalamus, and limbic structures.

137.name: Frontomarginal Gyrus
137.description: Anterior-most lateral frontal gyrus integrating multisensory information for complex cognition.
functions: Supports abstract reasoning, multitasking, and metacognitive awareness.
Participates in social and emotional evaluation.
connections: Receives input from temporal pole, parietal association areas, and limbic cortex.
Projects to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, and caudate.

138.name: Frontal Pole
138.description: Extreme anterior tip of frontal lobe involved in prospective reasoning and self-generated goals.
functions: Supports long-range planning, exploration, and default mode network processing.
Integrates internal goals with social cognition.
connections: Interconnects with medial prefrontal, orbitofrontal, and temporal association cortices.
Projects to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, basal ganglia, and limbic circuits.

139.name: Perirhinal Gyrus
139.description: Medial temporal cortical region linking object recognition with memory consolidation.
functions: Supports familiarity-based recognition memory and semantic associations.
Integrates visual feature information for memory encoding.
connections: Receives input from inferior temporal visual areas and amygdala.
Projects to entorhinal cortex, hippocampus, and orbitofrontal cortex.

140.name: Optic Radiation
140.description: Fan-shaped fiber pathway carrying visual signals from thalamus to occipital cortex.
functions: Transmits retinotopic information necessary for conscious vision.
Supports visual field processing including macular representation.
connections: Originates in lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
Terminates in primary visual cortex along the calcarine fissure.

141.name: Atrium of Lateral Ventricle
141.description: Trigonal expansion of lateral ventricle where temporal and occipital horns converge.
functions: Serves as CSF reservoir adjacent to hippocampal tail and splenium.
Provides anatomical reference for neurosurgical and imaging landmarks.
connections: Continuous with body, temporal horn, and occipital horn of lateral ventricle.
Contains choroid plexus tuft connecting to temporal horn.
